df-dip
blocks.content: Define a function that maps a normed complex vector space to its inner product operation in case its norm satisfies the parallelogram identity (otherwise the operation is still defined, but not meaningful). Based on Exercise 4(a) of [ReedSimon] p. 63 and Theorem 6.44 of [Ponnusamy] p. 361. Vector addition is ` ( 1st `` w ) ` , the scalar product is ` ( 2nd `` w ) ` , and the norm is ` n ` . (Contributed by NM, 10-Apr-2007.) (New usage is discouraged.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-dip(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3) {
  |- wceq(cdip, cmpt(s0, cnv, cmpo(s1, s2, cfv(cba, cv(s0)), cfv(cba, cv(s0)), co(csu(s3, co(nat1, cfz, nat4), co(co(ci, cexp, cv(s3)), cmul, co(cfv(cfv(cnmcv, cv(s0)), co(cv(s1), cfv(cpv, cv(s0)), co(co(ci, cexp, cv(s3)), cfv(cns, cv(s0)), cv(s2)))), cexp, nat2))), cdiv, nat4))))
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
}

axiom df-dip(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3) {
  ⊢ .iOLD =(s0 ∈ NrmCVec ↦(s1 ∈(BaseSet ` s0), s2 ∈(BaseSet ` s0)↦(sum(s3 ∈(1[...]4),((i[^]s3)[×](((normCV ` s0)`(s1[(+v ` s0)]((i[^]s3)[(.sOLD ` s0)]s2)))[^]2)))[÷]4)))
  ⊣ d(s0, s3)

  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, s2)

blocks.name: dipfval
blocks.content: The inner product function on a normed complex vector space. The definition is meaningful for vector spaces that are also inner product spaces, i.e. satisfy the parallelogram law. (Contributed by NM, 10-Apr-2007.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 16-Nov-2013.) (New usage is discouraged.)

blocks.name: ipval
blocks.content: Value of the inner product. The definition is meaningful for normed complex vector spaces that are also inner product spaces, i.e. satisfy the parallelogram law, although for convenience we define it for any normed complex vector space. The vector (group) addition operation is ` G ` , the scalar product is ` S ` , the norm is ` N ` , and the set of vectors is ` X ` . Equation 6.45 of [Ponnusamy] p. 361. (Contributed by NM, 31-Jan-2007.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 16-Nov-2013.) (New usage is discouraged.)

blocks.name: ipidsq
blocks.content: The inner product of a vector with itself is the square of the vector's norm. Equation I4 of [Ponnusamy] p. 362. (Contributed by NM, 1-Feb-2007.) (New usage is discouraged.)

blocks.name: dipcj
blocks.content: The complex conjugate of an inner product reverses its arguments. Equation I1 of [Ponnusamy] p. 362. (Contributed by NM, 1-Feb-2007.) (New usage is discouraged.)

  dipcj(c0, c1, c2, c3, c4)

  syl6eq(cfv(ccj, co(c3, c4, c1)), nat0, cfv(ccj, nat0), wceq(co(c3, c4, c1), nat0))
  fveq2(co(c3, c4, c1), nat0, ccj)
  cj0()
  eqeq1d(cfv(ccj, co(c3, c4, c1)), nat0, co(c1, c4, c3), w3a(wcel(c0, cnv), wcel(c1, c2), wcel(c3, c2)))

blocks.name: dip0l
blocks.content: Inner product with a zero first argument. Part of proof of Theorem 6.44 of [Ponnusamy] p. 361. (Contributed by NM, 5-Feb-2007.) (New usage is discouraged.)
blocks.origin:
thm dip0l(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4) {
  |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, cnv), wcel(c1, c2)), wceq(co(c3, c4, c1), nat0))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cba, c0))
  -| wceq(c3, cfv(cn0v, c0))
  -| wceq(c4, cfv(cdip, c0))
} = {
  eqtr3d(co(c3, c4, c1), nat0, cfv(ccj, co(c1, c4, c3)), wa(wcel(c0, cnv), wcel(c1, c2)))
  mpd3an3(wcel(c0, cnv), wcel(c1, c2), wceq(cfv(ccj, co(c1, c4, c3)), co(c3, c4, c1)), wcel(c3, c2))
  adantr(wcel(c0, cnv), wcel(c1, c2), wcel(c3, c2))
  nvzcl(c0, c3, c2)
  dipcj(c0, c1, c2, c3, c4)
  syl6eq(cfv(ccj, co(c1, c4, c3)), nat0, cfv(ccj, nat0), wa(wcel(c0, cnv), wcel(c1, c2)))
  fveq2d(ccj, co(c1, c4, c3), nat0, wa(wcel(c0, cnv), wcel(c1, c2)))
  dip0r(c0, c1, c2, c4, c3)

}

thm ipz(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4) {
  |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, cnv), wcel(c1, c2)), wb(wceq(co(c1, c3, c1), nat0), wceq(c1, c4)))

  -| wceq(c4, cfv(cn0v, c0))
  -| wceq(c3, cfv(cdip, c0))
